column3: Carmen Gillespie
<font color='#008080'>--e-s-p-i-e.</font>
Brenda Marie Osbey
<font color='navy'>Brenda Marie Osbey, B-r-e-n-d-a M-a-r-i-e O-s-b-e-y.</font>
Carmen Gillespie
<font color='#008080'>Brenda last night you were reading, the poem Nina Simone, and I was wondering if you could talk a little bit about how she's been a figure of inspiration, or--</font>
Brenda Marie Osbey

<font color='navy'>The Nina Simone poem came about almost exactly as it's described in the poem. I was away from New Orleans in Provincetown, Massachusetts, in fact, and a friend called, and told me</font>
<font color='navy'>a story about a Nina Simone concert, where she indeed did curse the audience out.</font>

<font color='navy'>And that got me thinking about Nina Simone as a kind of an image, as an overpowering image of my girlhood. My best girlfriend Marceline and I really did have an incident where her sister came into the</font>
<font color='navy'>bedroom and found us messing with her stuff, and said to us, if we wanted to be so grown, blah, blah, blah, blah, blah.</font>

<font color='navy'>And so the story about the Nina Simone concert, sparked a series of memories about moments in time, when Nina Simone as a kind of iconic figure, sort of rose to the fore in what seemed a very personal</font>
<font color='navy'>way. And so that was how the poem started, it really did sort of bring back those kinds of memories of experiences.</font>
Carmen Gillespie

<font color='#008080'>In the poem, it seems to me Nina Simone is a symbol of the rejected Black artist, and the artist specifically rejected by the African American community. Are there other figures that</font>
<font color='#008080'>you see fitting into that paradigm or, or how do you relate her position to the position of the African American artist generally?</font>
Brenda Marie Osbey

<font color='navy'>It isn't so much that it represents a rejection, I think, as as a tendency to take things for granted, and to take people for granted, and to take singers and poets and artists and</font>

<font color='navy'>voices, all of whom, and all of which represent us-- to take those things for granted because they are in fact there. And because they're part and parcel of the community, they are part of who we are.</font>

<font color='navy'>And so... I think it's just an indication of an age and a time and a sense of what makes sense, of what is right. It's only when we look back later, that it seems that we've committed some-- some</font>
<font color='navy'>great error, some great sin as it were.</font>

<font color='navy'>And, but she becomes in the poem far more symbolic of that entire tendency. But I mean, if you think of popular singers, and how popular singers go in and out of vogue and in and out of style, that</font>
<font color='navy'>kind of thing happens all the time. What was different about Nina Simone was that she represented an era.</font>
<font color='navy'>And my sense is that she knew that she represented that era. And there was a certain kind of cooperation and participation that was expected of all of the rest of us.</font>

<font color='navy'>And my sense, I have a very strong sense that we did not hold up our end of the bargain, but that perhaps there was no way for us to know that until it was too late anyway. And so the poem is a poem</font>

<font color='navy'>about regret. But it's regret about a situation that really can't be changed. And maybe the tone is not so much regret, as as it says it's a kind of recounting a kind of telling to play back against</font>
<font color='navy'>those other images. When we in fact were all the evening news.</font>

<font color='navy'>And it's an attempt to capture, maybe not one era, but a series of eras. And Nina Simone seems to be present throughout. She seems now to have been a constant. And the poem is a sense of our-- of a</font>
<font color='navy'>kind of communal regret, personalized, where the speaker takes on the confessional attitude of the group, of the community, of the "We".</font>
Carmen Gillespie

<font color='#008080'>And then the other poem you read last night you referred to sugar as such a central part of the African diaspora, one of the main motivations for the slave trade being the production</font>
<font color='#008080'>of sugar. Was your poem an attempt to re-appropriate or reclaim sugar as a part of our experience in a more positive sense?</font>
Brenda Marie Osbey

<font color='navy'>Well, I come from a place where sugar is very important. Louisiana was a sugar state. And the portion of the poem that I read-- it's a rather long poem, and I read an excerpt from</font>

<font color='navy'>it. And so that portion is the introduction to the topic of sugar. And much later in the poem, there's all this stuff about the processing of sugar, and the growing of sugar and all of this stuff.</font>

<font color='navy'>But it also-- there are a series of plays on that word sugar, and the many ways that we use it: we call one another sugar, and so forth. And the poem is an attempt to look at the paradox of this</font>
<font color='navy'>sweet, sticky substance, that is also the source of rum, the intoxicating substance,</font>

<font color='navy'>and that that seems to say so much about our experience in the New World-- sugar was one of the reasons we were here. And we produce sugar, and we consume sugar. And when we are ill with diabetes, we</font>
<font color='navy'>say that we have sugar. And we call one another sugar. And we sugarcoat things.</font>

<font color='navy'>And in a city like New Orleans, of course, one of the things we're famous for is pastries, and sweets. And we have all kinds of names for various kinds of sweet, sweet, sweet goods and sweet foods.</font>

<font color='navy'>And one of the ones that is typical of New Orleans is hot calas, and calas are rice cakes, which of course there's a double meaning there because we also were a rice area, Louisiana was rather, not</font>
<font color='navy'>New Orleans.</font>

<font color='navy'>And so rice and sugar together-- compounding of the experience of the enslaved and oppressed. And also, there's a lot of bodily imagery in the poem, because of course this is intense, backbreaking</font>
<font color='navy'>labor. And so the poem is an attempt to look at-- not just at slavery, but at enslavement as a specific kind of violence,</font>

<font color='navy'>as a specific kind of action, and to personalize it in a way that perhaps makes sense to us. One of my firmest beliefs is that no one ever thought of herself as a slave. That "slave" was not anyone's</font>
<font color='navy'>name or job title or, or any other such thing that, that people were persons first, in their own mind's eye and their own imagination prior to anything else.</font>

<font color='navy'>And so in the poem, I create a series of characters who speak. And it's called a cautionary, a cautionary fabulous, a cautionary tale. The title is, "How to Make Sugar, a Cautionary Fabulous Writ</font>
<font color='navy'>Small".</font>

<font color='navy'>So one of the things that the poem does is it appropriates the colonial and colonizing voice, the dehumanizing voice, but writing against that constantly. And I think the authoritative voice in the</font>
<font color='navy'>poem is the voice of the woman who speaks and who is spoken about and who is written about and who is unreachable, unattainable and who remains removed from all of this.</font>

<font color='navy'>And backing her up, I suppose, are the women who are called the vendeurs, the sellers. And there are marketplace scenes and so forth in which the women are observed and observe others observing them.</font>
<font color='navy'>So it's a poem about representation, and a poem about the making of a series of images,</font>

<font color='navy'>and the whole sensual passage about the tying  of the tignon, and how important that is, and how it attaches to the free status of these particular women who are vendeurs. I think it's an important</font>
<font color='navy'>point to make that even within the free Black community there is this obsession with containment and tying and burdening.</font>

<font color='navy'>The difference there is that the vendeurs, these free Black women, are doing their own form of containment and tying. Their heads are tied in these sumptuous cloths. There's a passage later on in the</font>
<font color='navy'>poem that I didn't read, that talks about how they layer their ankles in gold and silver bracelets because this represents their freedom, oddly enough.</font>
<font color='navy'>And-- so it's a poem about the making of an image and perhaps the remaking and the reconstituting of a self against such incredible odds, I think. I could be wrong.</font>
Carmen Gillespie

<font color='#008080'>Your work, obviously, is deeply rooted in New Orleans and its history, and its African American communities. Can you speak a little bit about how you see yourself, potentially as a</font>
<font color='#008080'>New Orleans poet?</font>
Brenda Marie Osbey

<font color='navy'>I think it's the most important thing about the work I do is that it's-- it all grows out of an attempt to understand something about New Orleans. One of the things that growing up</font>
<font color='navy'>in New Orleans does is it gives you a sense of an essentially intact cultural environment.</font>

<font color='navy'>And of a cultural environment that is its own thing that clearly is African American, but is African American in its own rather specific, and improvised upon, and constantly improvising way. And so</font>
<font color='navy'>I've spent most of my writing life studying New Orleans, studying the African presence in New Orleans, studying traditional religion in New Orleans,</font>

<font color='navy'>as a way of understanding something about perspective, I suppose. Something about perspective, something about shape, something about how things are made. Because the poem-- I love the word poetry,</font>

<font color='navy'>the word poem. Poesis, the made thing, it is a thing that is made that is constructed that has its own entity in the world. Once it is made, it's apart from me. And it's no longer mine.</font>

<font color='navy'>And it stands out there, if it's any good, it stands out there on its own without me to support it. And so I think that something about New Orleans, something about the specific history of slavery</font>
<font color='navy'>endured there, something about the very specific kinds of resistance, something about our peculiar dance forms, things like the second line,</font>

<font color='navy'>things like hot calas, the bending of form, the recreating, and the fracturing of form, and space, and time, a kind of disbelief even in time; that history isn't the past, history is what happens. And</font>

<font color='navy'>so history is acting in us, we are acting in it, and we were acting upon it all of the time, that it's always all going on. And that's the beauty of the dance that we call second line,</font>

<font color='navy'>that while the primary procession is taking place, the formal procession is taking place, there's this band, or rather there are multiple bands of people gathered along the side, who are doing these</font>

<font color='navy'>other things. And each time they do the other thing, it takes a different form. Nobody dances the second line exactly the same way twice. There's certain basic steps, certain basic movements, and you</font>
<font color='navy'>do countless variations on those.</font>

<font color='navy'>And the beauty of the thing is that somehow we all can do it, I don't know any New Orleanians who can't do it, we all can do it. We all recognize it when we see it. And yet we all do it differently.</font>
<font color='navy'>We know what is and is not second line. But it's always changing, it's constantly changing. And-- so everything is always happening.</font>

<font color='navy'>And it isn't an ahistorical approach. It's probably a multi-layered approach to history as a thing from within, as opposed to a thing imposed from without. And that's the thing is that I have a</font>
<font color='navy'>fascination with history. And I have a fascination with poets who have a problem with history.</font>

<font color='navy'>And I think some of our greatest poets, certainly some of our greatest narrative poets have a problem with history. And that is the thing that makes them so compelling. Robert Hayden has a problem</font>

<font color='navy'>with history, and so he writes in history, in order to work out these narrative moments and to make them real to us. Gayl Jones has a problem with history, and she's always rediscovering it and</font>
<font color='navy'>reshaping it.</font>

<font color='navy'>Sherley Anne Williams has a problem with history in her long narrative poems. Jay Wright has a problem with history. And so history becomes the problem. It becomes the thing that you look at, the</font>

<font color='navy'>thing that you worry, the thing that you finger. It's the scab, it's the sore, and you work around it constantly. It's always there, and it never quite goes away. It's never finished. And therefore</font>
<font color='navy'>neither are we.</font>

<font color='navy'>So that we're constantly working, and it isn't so much revising, as it is re-visioning. That we have to learn to see history in our own image, so to speak. We have to, I think, learn and we have to</font>
<font color='navy'>teach ourselves over and over again what our history really is, and what our place is in our history, or histories.</font>
Carmen Gillespie

<font color='#008080'>So, poetry in some ways it sounds like is a way of rewriting official histories in your work. I'm wondering if the form, the long poem particularly, allows you to deal with your</font>
<font color='#008080'>concerns about simultaneity of experience, multiplicity, and improvisation?</font>
Brenda Marie Osbey

<font color='navy'>Yeah, the long narrative poem-- it seems to me the older I get the longer the poems get! The long narrative poem has become for me an ideal form. On the one hand, it's quite open,</font>
<font color='navy'>you can do all kinds of things, you can have a multitude of narrative and lyric voices happening in there. Recently, I've been experimenting with rhyme in the long poem.</font>

<font color='navy'>And it's an open form. And yet, at the same time, it's a form that breaks certain boundaries, in a very conscientious way. When we think of narrative, I think it's common to think of a story with a</font>
<font color='navy'>beginning, middle, and end. And yet, if you look at truly fine narrative poems, that doesn't exist in truly fine narrative, narrative poems.</font>
In Robert Hayden's Middle Passage, for instance, there is not a beginning, middle and end. We begin in the middle or at the end, we can't tell which it is, it depends on who's actually reading
<font color='navy'>the poem. But we have snippets and passages and excerpts of things, of documents, of things that both support and critique reality.</font>

<font color='navy'>And because we have all of that laid bare for us, it's like walking into a room where we have the option to rearrange everything each time we enter the room. Or perhaps each time we enter the room, we</font>

<font color='navy'>see the room as a different environment, and we organize it to suit our purposes for that moment. So that the poem exists in a kind of moment that is that moment at that time.</font>
Carmen Gillespie
<font color='#008080'>So then the poem exists-- or does it create then a whole? Or is it another type of representation of a fragmentation?</font>
Brenda Marie Osbey

<font color='navy'>I wonder that there are these wholes that we constantly seek out. I wonder. I was raised in a tradition that believes very much in whole, in the whole, in the beauty of the whole.</font>

<font color='navy'>That a thing is good when it is beautiful, a thing is beautiful when it is whole, that wholeness and beauty and health all go together, that those are all the same thing. And so on the one hand I was</font>
<font color='navy'>brought up in a tradition that holds very dearly to that principle.</font>

<font color='navy'>And yet at the same time, the poems that I write are by nature fragmentary, and purposely fragmenting the scene, or the character, or the speaker, or the narrative, or the image.</font>

<font color='navy'>There are lots of images of broken things, and sometimes stanzas seem to end at a point where nothing has actually happened. Something might be about to happen. But we don't know yet what that is, and</font>

<font color='navy'>we don't find out in that poem. So that we get bits and pieces. And the thing is, it isn't the story that's important, it is the thing that, eventually, we begin to realize as readers.</font>

<font color='navy'>It isn't the story that matters in the narrative poem, it's how the story is being told, why the story is being told. And who are the voices telling these stories? And do we trust them? Do we know</font>
<font color='navy'>them? Are they us?</font>

<font color='navy'>So it's about possibilities, I think, much more so than about the story itself. And I think that's a major difference between the writing of prose fiction, and the writing of the narrative poem, that</font>
<font color='navy'>the purpose is different. My purpose is never to tell a story when I start out.</font>

<font color='navy'>What happens is that I come across a story, I find a story, or a story finds me, and I find it compelling in some way, and try to see how many ways I can approach that story, and how many versions or</font>
<font color='navy'>voices that story might exist in. And sometimes within the same character, within the same narrative, within the same narrator, there might be multiple voices going on, so.</font>
Carmen Gillespie
<font color='#008080'>And in terms of the larger picture of African American poetry, do you have a sense of yourself as a part of a movement or part of a contemporary sensibility?</font>
Brenda Marie Osbey

<font color='navy'>A part of a movement, I would say probably not, in all honesty, probably not. I started publishing in the late 1970s, and I certainly have some major influences and some major</font>
<font color='navy'>references, I think.</font>

<font color='navy'>But I've never, I've never been a joiner. And so I've never seen my work as belonging to a particular movement. I do see that it belongs in a certain moment, though. But those are really questions, I</font>
<font color='navy'>suppose, to be determined later, after the passage of much time.</font>

<font color='navy'>But I do see African American poetry attempting to acquire a new freshness, a new kind of experimentation with language that is perhaps not quite so reverent as it once was, that there is a newly</font>
<font color='navy'>awakened sense of play,</font>

<font color='navy'>and a newly awakened sense of-- and when I talk about play, I'm talking about taking a kind of joy in the language and seeing the language as the instrument that it is. So that there is not such an</font>
<font color='navy'>awe of the beauty of language, that we can also toy with the ugliness of language.</font>

<font color='navy'>And that we can represent horrible things in beautiful language is one of the most shocking, one of the most shocking things. I think it happens in prose fiction quite a lot as well. There's that</font>

<font color='navy'>beautiful passage in Toni Morrison's Beloved where Sethe is attempting to behead her child because the slavers are coming. And it's one of the most beautiful passages, I think, in the English</font>
<font color='navy'>language.</font>

<font color='navy'>And there is a kind of holy quiet that surrounds that moment. That's the moment of poetry. That's the stuff that we that we hold to and cling to, and embrace. And yet the act is so horrible, that we</font>
<font color='navy'>are able to see a kind of beauty in it.</font>
Carmen Gillespie

<font color='#008080'>Holy quiet. That's a lovely phrase. I'm thinking about your knowledge of language, and languages, and I'm wondering how being fluent in several languages influences your own work,</font>
<font color='#008080'>and your understanding of the complexities of language and meaning.</font>
Brenda Marie Osbey
<font color='navy'>I would say I have an obsession with language and languages, and that I collect language and languages, I suppose, in the way that other people collect objects.</font>

<font color='navy'>And it goes back pretty far, I suppose. I've always had a fascination with language and with languages, because something tells me that there's always something in there, there's always some</font>

<font color='navy'>possibility in there. And of course, there are things that we can express in certain languages that we can't express in other languages there-- finally, there are things that are non-translatable.</font>

<font color='navy'>There's no French word for gumbo. Because the concept doesn't exist, because the experience doesn't exist, because the ingredients don't exist. So you make it as best you possibly can in this other</font>

<font color='navy'>environment, but you have to call it gumbo. That's what it is. And... and yet there's a layering that takes place there. There's a layering of experience, and a layering of language.</font>

<font color='navy'>And one of the things that fascinates me about Black folk, wherever we find them is the extent to which we have always joyed in language. We're a tongue people. We believe in loose tongues and free</font>

<font color='navy'>tongues. And one of the things that I think it's very easy to forget nowadays with the 21st century, one of the things that's very easy to forget, is that we came to the new world as a multilingual</font>
<font color='navy'>people.</font>

<font color='navy'>And we perhaps lost or discarded languages along the way. And I think there's a kind of imperative that we make some attempt to reclaim some of those languages, as best we possibly can. And to embrace</font>
<font color='navy'>language.</font>

<font color='navy'>And language is one of those things that's, of course, always been used against us as a tool, as a weapon. And it's the kind of thing that we've always embraced and said-- a perfect example of that is</font>

<font color='navy'>Creole language. You take the master's language, which might be French or Spanish or Portuguese or Dutch. And you say this is your language. This is the language of the master. This is the language in</font>
<font color='navy'>which you control me. This is the language in which you turn me into an abject object. This is the language in which you denigrate me.</font>

<font color='navy'>doing with this language now? Can you speak this language. And of course, the reality is that you find very few people who are not born into a creole speaking environment, who speak those languages</font>
<font color='navy'>and understand those languages.</font>

<font color='navy'>And even when we translate those languages into our use of English, which certainly is what happens in a place like Louisiana, you find us coming up with these newly concocted arrangements of language</font>
<font color='navy'>and turns of phrase,</font>

<font color='navy'>and that's the thing I think, where we find beauty in the language is it's the turn of phrase. It isn't the funny spellings of plantation dialect. And poets who use Black folk speech, we're never</font>

<font color='navy'>really trying to do plantation dialect that was imposed from the exterior. They were trying to capture the authenticity of Black skill: the ability to improvise and to make language, to make words.</font>

<font color='navy'>And finally, that's what poetry is really all about. More so I think than all of the other literary art forms, poetry is lodged in language, and you have to go through the language-- there is no other</font>

<font color='navy'>way. If it doesn't exist in the poem, if it doesn't exist in the text, then it ain't there. And you can't, you can't put it there, you have to enter the poem through the language. And part of what</font>
<font color='navy'>that means is that you have to be able to enter the poet's world.</font>
Carmen Gillespie

<font color='#008080'>And is that-- entering the poet's world, minority poets or African American poets-- do you find that that's a particularly difficult thing for audiences to do, or how do you</font>
<font color='#008080'>negotiate that gap as a poet?</font>
Brenda Marie Osbey

<font color='navy'>It's less difficult for audiences to do it I think, than for academics and critics to do. Because, again, academics and critics frequently are imposing an external structure. And</font>

<font color='navy'>the difference that we see is--  I think it's best illustrated when we look at the difference in audience response at a live poetry reading, and the dearth of criticism and critical study of African</font>
<font color='navy'>American poetry.</font>

<font color='navy'>Huge gap, there's a huge gap there. The audience listening to the poem, seeing the poem, hearing the poem being performed, understands the poem, grasps the poem, responds to the poem in the moment.</font>

<font color='navy'>And that's a wonderful thing to be a part of. One of the best things about poetry is the live poetry reading. Because there's a kind of energy that takes place, there's something that passes between</font>
<font color='navy'>the poet and the audience, when it's working.</font>

<font color='navy'>When everything is going well, there's this energy that passes back and forth between the poet and the audience. And we feed on that, it's a mutual thing. That doesn't necessarily happen with the</font>

<font color='navy'>critic. It doesn't necessarily happen. Because there's this attempt to impose this order from outside. And one of the things that the poet, of course, wants to do is to break the rules, and to destroy</font>
<font color='navy'>the order, and perhaps to create a new order.</font>
Carmen Gillespie

<font color='#008080'>Well, I mean we were talking about the importance of performance, it sounds to me, in terms of your own work and energy that you derive from audiences. How would you distinguish what</font>
<font color='#008080'>you do in poetry reading from spoken word poetry [inaudible]?</font>
Brenda Marie Osbey

<font color='navy'>I think it's quite different. I could be very wrong about this, but spoken word seems to me to involve a truly theatrical bent and intent. I think what happens when I'm reading,</font>
<font color='navy'>I'm trying to read well,</font>

<font color='navy'>I'm trying to read the poem in the voices that are speaking in the poem whether there are narrators functioning as actual narrators or not, and that's quite different. And I think what happens also is</font>
<font color='navy'>that there is the ability to improvise, it's not that I'm reading words that aren't on the page, or that I'm leaving out words that are on the page.</font>

<font color='navy'>But each reading of the poem is going to be different than every other reading of the poem, a poem like the Nina Simone poem-- there are occasions where I will read it with more or less verve, with</font>
<font color='navy'>more or less bounce, with more or less volume, with more or less emphasis on certain lines, phrases, stanzas.</font>

<font color='navy'>And that happens-- very, much of that happens in the moment when the poet realizes who that audience is and what that response is like, and so it becomes a kind of a wave that you ride.</font>
Carmen Gillespie
<font color='#008080'>And you're saying to come back to that idea of improvisation?</font>
Carmen Gillespie
<font color='#008080'>And what are you working on now [inaudible] projects?</font>
Brenda Marie Osbey
<font color='navy'>Mmhmm.</font>
Brenda Marie Osbey

<font color='navy'>Lots of things. I'm working on lots of things. I'm working on a series of essays about my experiences in France, going back to France after more than 20 years, 30-some years, 30</font>
<font color='navy'>years I guess.</font>

<font color='navy'>I did my undergrad as-- part of my undergraduate studies I did in France and returned to the southern region for six months to work on a new book project that's a bilingual French-English (smattering</font>
<font color='navy'>of Creole), project about slavery and resistance in Louisiana under the French colonial regime. So that's one project, and then there are two other poetry manuscripts.</font>

<font color='navy'>Also having to do with Louisiana, with New Orleans as a topic. But one of them does a lot of experimentation with rhyme, which I've never used, or never used to great effect before. I also write</font>
<font color='navy'>creative nonfiction. So there's a body of essays that I'm working on right now.</font>

<font color='navy'>And then there is a series of, I guess, for lack of a better word, dispatches about my experiences returning to France after all of those years, looking at French racism, which not only has not</font>
<font color='navy'>improved in the past 30 years, but has intensified and worsened in rather graphic ways.</font>

<font color='navy'>And so there're always a number of projects going on when, when I'm working well, I'm working on a number of projects. Because just because one thing isn't going well, at one moment, doesn't mean that</font>
<font color='navy'>I can't work on something else. So there's always something, some iron in the fire.</font>
Carmen Gillespie

<font color='#008080'>The way that you're speaking of your experiences in France and New Orleans, it seems to me that you've constructed yourself in feeling as if you're a person with multiple influences</font>

<font color='#008080'>and multiple identities in terms of your heritage. And I'm wondering how the label of African American either fits that description or fits your self-- your self-structure or in some ways may even be</font>
<font color='#008080'>limiting?</font>
Brenda Marie Osbey

<font color='navy'>I think it fits perfectly. I think it's about as precise and as exact as we can get. I really think it is because it means a lot of different things at the same time. Of course,</font>

<font color='navy'>historically, we're an African people in the Americas. And there're so many versions and variations of that. And of course, there's a tendency to think of African American as a monolith, which of</font>
<font color='navy'>course, it never is, never was.</font>

<font color='navy'>And there has been a tendency sometimes on the part of critics looking at my work to say, well, this is not African American, this is not Black-- this is New Orleans. And while New Orleans certainly</font>
<font color='navy'>is its own space, its own culture, that space and that culture have always been Black space.</font>

<font color='navy'>And so it's one of those-- one of the things that I always say is that when we make those kinds of distinctions, that slavery under the French was better or slavery under the Spaniards was better or</font>
